exercise.title: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
exercise.groundedDescription: By engaging your five senses, you've successfully anchored yourself in the present moment.

immediateStability.title: Immediate Stability
immediateStability.description: Connect with your environment and feel grounded

mentalClarity.title: Mental Clarity
mentalClarity.description: Interrupt racing thoughts and regain focus

calmPresence.title: Calm Presence
calmPresence.description: Feel more present and in control

items.text: Something with a interesting color or pattern
items.guidance: Look for textures, reflections, or color combinations that catch your eye
Notice how light hits the surface - is it glossy, matte, or somewhere in between?

items.text: Something that's moving or has shadows
items.guidance: Watch how movement creates changing patterns of light and shadow

items.text: A detail you hadn't noticed before
items.guidance: Look closer at familiar objects - what small details have you missed?
Focus on why this object feels comforting - its colors, shape, or memories it holds

touch.title: Feel around you
touch.subtitle: Find 4 things you can touch or feel

items.text: The temperature of the air on your skin
items.guidance: Notice if it's warm, cool, or neutral - how does it feel on different parts of your body?
Feel the fabric between your fingers - is it soft, rough, smooth, or textured?

items.text: The surface you're sitting or standing on
items.guidance: Press into it slightly - is it firm, soft, warm, or cool against your body?

items.text: Something smooth or rough near you
items.guidance: Run your fingers along the surface - notice the contrast in textures
Close your eyes and focus inward - can you hear your breath or pulse?
Listen beyond the room - what distant sounds can you identify?
Notice quiet sounds like humming electronics, air movement, or settling noises
Take a slow, deep breath - is it fresh, stale, scented, or neutral?
Look for subtle scents - coffee, soap, fabric softener, or natural smells

items.text: The current taste in your mouth
items.guidance: Run your tongue around your mouth - sweet, salty, minty, or just the taste of saliva?

howItWorks.title: How 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding Works
howItWorks.description1: The 5-4-3-2-1 technique works by redirecting your brain's attention from anxious thoughts to immediate sensory experiences. When anxiety activates your brain's threat-detection system, deliberately engaging each of your five senses creates competing neural signals that interrupt the anxiety response.
howItWorks.description2: By systematically identifying things you can see, touch, hear, smell, and taste, you shift your nervous system from a state of hyperarousal to present-moment awareness. This sensory engagement activates the prefrontal cortex—your brain's reasoning center—which helps regulate the amygdala, the emotional alarm system that triggers anxiety.
howItWorks.description3: The countdown structure (5-4-3-2-1) provides cognitive scaffolding that gives your mind a concrete task, preventing it from spiraling into worry while simultaneously anchoring you to your physical environment and the present moment.

sensoryEngagement.title: Sensory Engagement
sensoryEngagement.description: Activating multiple senses simultaneously creates strong neural signals that compete with and override anxiety patterns in the brain.

neuralInterruption.title: Neural Interruption
neuralInterruption.description: The structured countdown task engages your prefrontal cortex, interrupting the amygdala's anxiety response and restoring rational thought.

presentMomentAnchoring.title: Present Moment Anchoring
presentMomentAnchoring.description: Identifying concrete sensory details roots your awareness in the here-and-now, breaking the cycle of past rumination or future worry.

science.title: The Science Behind 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
science.description: Research demonstrates that sensory grounding techniques produce measurable improvements in anxiety symptoms across diverse populations. In a randomized controlled trial of 121 children with Tourette Syndrome, grounding exercises led to a 36-point reduction in anxiety scores—significantly greater than controls—with particularly strong effects on separation anxiety (11.31-point reduction, effect size 0.55) and social anxiety (11.05-point reduction, effect size 0.65).

anxietyReduction.title: Anxiety Reduction in Clinical Populations
anxietyReduction.description: In children with Tourette Syndrome, a protocol incorporating sensory grounding achieved a 36.02-point reduction in total anxiety scores, with separation anxiety dropping by 11.31 points (effect size 0.55) and social anxiety by 11.05 points (effect size 0.65).

mentalHealthImprovement.title: Mental Health & Functioning Improvements
mentalHealthImprovement.description: Patients with functional neurological disorder using the 5-4-3-2-1 grounding technique showed a 39-point increase in mental health scores, 35-point improvement in emotional functioning, and halved their impairment levels from 25.7 to 13.2 on disability scales.

symptomFrequencyReduction.title: Symptom Frequency Reduction
symptomFrequencyReduction.description: A meta-analysis of psychological treatments incorporating sensory grounding showed 82% of patients achieved at least 50% reduction in functional seizure frequency, with sustained improvements at 6-month follow-up and accompanying anxiety score reductions.

whenToPractice.title: When To Practice
items: During panic attacks or acute anxiety episodes to interrupt the escalation cycle
When feeling overwhelmed, dissociated, or disconnected from your surroundings
Before stressful events like presentations or difficult conversations to establish calm
After traumatic triggers or flashbacks to reconnect with the present moment

whatYoullNotice.title: What You'll Notice
items: Immediate reduction in racing thoughts and mental overwhelm within the first minute
Slowed heart rate and decreased physical tension as your nervous system calms
Clearer thinking and improved ability to respond rather than react to situations
Greater sense of control and stability when practiced regularly during stress

tip1.title: Go Slow
tip1.description: Take your time identifying each sensory detail—rushing defeats the purpose. Spend 5-10 seconds really observing each item you identify.

tip2.title: Be Specific
tip2.description: Instead of "I see a chair," try "I see a wooden chair with curved armrests and a red cushion." Detailed observation strengthens the grounding effect.

tip3.title: Repeat When Needed
tip3.description: If anxiety returns after one round, immediately do another. You can practice this technique as many times as necessary until you feel grounded.
